thig7.2:1.2: You might consider translating 'indriya' as 'abilities' (rather than 'faculties'). I've never liked the word 'faculties', it makes me think of college administrators rather than spiritual abilities.
thig7.2:1.3: 'Paṭivijjhi' is 2nd or 3rd person, not 1st. So this is either "She mastered" or "You mastered." Based on the subsequent sentences, it seems to me that it's probably "You mastered".
thig7.2:1.4: I think both of these words are adjectives for 'padaṁ santaṁ.' I might translate this as something like "You mastered the path of peace - the pacification of formations, true happiness." Or perhaps "You mastered the peaceful path; the joyful pacification of formations."
thig7.2:2.1: It is odd that the editor of the Pāli text has this as the beginning of a new quote from a new speaker. It seems to me that this is still the same person speaking as in the previous sentence.
thig7.2:3.4: or 'they are not masters of the Dhamma.'
thig7.2:4.2: 'appaṭipuggala' lit. means 'there is no person who is [his] counterpart' (ie, he has no equals)
thig7.2:4.3: no 'he' is needed here, nor is the comma at the end needed.
thig7.2:5.2: 'atikkama' means "going beyond" or "surpassing" ('ati-' means 'exceeding' and 'kamaṁ' means 'going')
thig7.2:5.3: "and the noble eightfold path" (no period at the end)
thig7.2:5.4: "which leads to the pacification of suffering" (note that it is 'dukkha - upasama' here, not 'dukkha - nirodha' as one would usually see)
thig7.2:6.2: Interesting that here you translate 'rata' as "devoted" (instead of "enjoying")
